body:
Thanks :) 

Regarding your problem, can you successfully run one of the example notebooks?

Dear developers,

Best wishes for this new year!

Yes, i tried to run the examples with success. I was even able to use talos with a short grid of only two lines (fixed LR, fixed momentum and 2 decays for SGD fine-tunning) and everything went just fine. But when I try to expand the parameters increasing the grid to 27 combinations, talos freezes after the fourth or fifth combination (for testing purposes, I am using rounds of only two epochs). It's just weird, don't you think? If you need to see the code, please, just let me know.

In advance, thank you for your support.

Ok, then we start digging :) Can you share with a sample of your data (n=10 is enough), your input model, param grid, and the Scan() command. In case the data is sensitive ie. you can't share it, you could share dummy data with the same format where your model runs successfully without Talos.

@mikkokotila, here are the elements you asked for (please, find them attached)!

The main programming lines used to explore Talos features:
[Code.pdf](https://github.com/autonomio/talos/files/2732570/Code.pdf)
[Code.docx](https://github.com/autonomio/talos/files/2732571/Code.docx)

Eclipse console results (freezing at 25% after running a few rounds):
[Eclipse_Console_Result.txt](https://github.com/autonomio/talos/files/2732580/Eclipse_Console_Result.txt)

Used dataset sample (around 450 images for training + validation):
[Subset-Leaves-General.zip](https://github.com/autonomio/talos/files/2732581/Subset-Leaves-General.zip)

Thank you very much for your help!
It seems that you are wrapping Talos experiment inside some kind of optimization function? Is that correct? What are you trying to achieve by doing this?

Yes, that's right. My aim is to obtain the best parameters among the ones shown in the code (LR, decay, momentum) to then return them as function result. I am aware the "return" instruction is missing; however, talos.Scan(...) frezees at 25% while running optimization over the dataset that I made available, thus preventing subsequent instruction of being executed.

When you say "function" result, do you mean that you want to end up with a function that can do predictions with the best model? 

If that's the case, you can achieve the same (cross-validated "best" model and the resulting predictions) in two very simple ways with just two lines of code:

```
scan_object = ta.Scan(x=x_train , y=y_train, params=p, model=gen_model)
scan_object_with_eval = ta.Autom8(scan_object, x_val, y_val)
```
The above will entail completing an entire pipeline from the scan to evaluation and predictions. The prediction and evaluation results will be added to the scan_object. 

For the most part, you might just want to be able to evaluate the models right there and then and not think about predictions yet, and that's when you can just simply:

```
scan_object = ta.Scan(x=x_train , y=y_train, params=p, model=gen_model)
scan_object.evaluate_models(x_val, y_val)
```
Would that do the job for you?

By the way, you can do the latter in a one-liner as well: 

`all_done = ta.Scan(x=x_train , y=y_train, params=p, model=gen_model).evaluate_models(x_val, y_val)`
@mikkokotila, i did not have the opportunity to test it yet, but looks good. I will try your suggestion as soon as possible and I'll let you now the results. Thank you ;)
I tried your suggestion but the outcome was the same... Talos scan stucks in the 25% of progress :S Should I test something else?

It depends on the OS you are on, but you can try: 

`ta.Scan(...  clear_tf_session=False  ...)`

Generally speaking, also looking at Keras issues where kernels silently die, the issue is caused by resource management (like running out of memory etc). Also some users report that kernel dying is fixed by updating conda (are you on conda?) and/or updating TensorFlow. Also updating cudNN have been reported to help. Can you try those and see what happens.

Wow! It worked! Thanks a lot!

Although, the "evaluate_models" method mencioned earlier is not working. Here is the result: 
  File "...\ML\MLTools.py", line 198, in gridSearch_Talos_SGD_TimeBasedShedule
    all_done = talos.Scan(x=X , y=Y, params=p, model=create_model, clear_tf_session=False).evaluate_models(Xval, Yval)
TypeError: func_evaluate() missing 1 required positional argument: 'y_val'

It looks like Scan method requires a 'y_val' parameter. I've also noticed that "evaluate_models" invocation seems to not be supported. Maybe, the object returned by talos.Scan does not have that definition...

What do you think?

Thank you very much for your help!

That's great :) You're most welcome.

To resolve the new issue you mention, you have to update to version >0.4.6 and it will work. 

`pip install git+https://github.com/autonomio/talos@dev`

Closing here. Feel free to open new issue if anything.

issue.title: Situation with the  "clear_tf_session" of talos.Scan

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
Dear Talos developer,

A few days ago, I reported an issue entitled "Talos grid search freezes after a few assays investigation" ( issue #159 ), which was solved thanks to your valuable advise: to use "clear_tf_session=False".

Well, now a similar matter brought me here to ask for your advise once again. When I request talos to scan 4 diferent SGD-based LR in a VGG architecture and using  "clear_tf_session=False", after the 3rd one some memory leaks (OOMs) are issued in the console. It looks like that SGD is more demanding for graphic cards memory (btw just to recall, I am using a couple of Quadro M4000 paired through SLI). Sometimes, scan fails due to OOM error. If I use "clear_tf_session=True", talos scan ends up to freeze unexpectedly, as it was reported before ( issue #159 ).

As you already figured out, I am in the middle of a dilemma. Would you help me out, please?

In advance, thank you for your attention!
